   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with A. Fib with RVR and bacteremia.
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures from [**Location (un) 78**] growing MSSA.  Source
   unclear. ESR and CRP are markedly elevated and patient has septic
   joints as well.  Presentation not convincing for pneumonia, but cannot
   definitely rule out.  LAT CXR not of high enough quality to visualize
   retrocardiac opacity.  ID recommended CT torso, however, patient
   creatinine is acutely elevated and contrast at this time is likely to
   result in further kidney injury.  Will defer bronchoscopy at present as
   patient has minimal secretions while intubated and no significant
   respiratory symptoms prior to intubation.  Sputum now growing GNRs.  If
   patient has increasing sputum or becomes febrile will consider adding
   gram negative coverage.  TEE on [**3-11**] was negative for vegetations on the
   valves and pacer lead, but given high grade bacteremia, a small
   vegetation may have been missed.
   - daily surveillance cultures
   - d4 nafcillin for MSSA bacteremia (Day 1 = [**2174-3-10**])
   - Will d/c daily EKGs to assess intervals
 not likely myositis
   - F/u mini-BAL results, per ID recs
   .
   # Septic arthritis / gout: Patient septic arthritis combined with gouty
   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - solumedrol 16 mg daily per rheum for gout; needs slow taper
   - ortho following, JP drain still in left knee
 F/u ortho recs
   .
   # Tachypnea/hypoxemia: Appears to be subacute exacerbation with decline
   over past 3-4 weeks.  No clear evidence of pneumonia by CXR although
   possible posterobasilar infiltrate.  Urinary Legionella antigen
   negative.   Lactate mildly elevated on presentation, but lower after
   fluid resuscitation.  Some evidence for COPD exacerbation by history
   and in setting of steroid taper, but does not explain bacteremia and
   new A. Fib with RVR.  V/Q scan with low probability for PE.  [**Month (only) 11**]
   represent mild diastolic dysfunction [**2-7**] to a. fib with RVR causing
   pulmonary edema.  Lastly would consider aspiration.  Patient electively
   intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Some difficulty
   weaning patient from vent early in the morning of [**3-13**].
   - Cont. to wean vent settings as tolerated
   - Antibiotics
   - nebulizers
   .
   # ARF: Likely predominantly pre-renal as patient appeared
   underresuscitated on presentation and urine lytes consistent with
   pre-renal etiology.  Previous baseline 1.3-1.5 at [**Hospital1 1**] [**Location (un) 78**]. LOS
   I/Os documentation
 includes 4L patient received prior to arriving in
   the ICU.  Patient received multiple boluses of IVF overnight for low
   urine outputs with CVPs 10-11.  No evidence of UTI currently.  Renal
   ultrasound yesterday with right-sided hydronephrosis (of note patient
   has a mass lesion in left kidney previously documented at [**Hospital1 **] [**Location (un) 78**])
   but no evidence of abscess. Pt does have positive WBC on U/A [**2174-3-11**],
   but thought to be contaminant [**2-7**] Foley
 add urine eosiniphils and
   repeat U/A
   - F/u Urology c/s (moderate right hydronephrosis)
   - Renal c/s in AM for worsening kidney failure.
   - renally dose meds (decrease nafcillin to 2 g Q6H if creatinine >
   4.0)
   - NS boluses and blood prn
   .
   # Tachycardia: A. Fib with RVR
 appears to be a new diagnosis for this
   patient.  Likely not a candidate for coumadin given recent GI bleed and
   colon cancer.  Patient has ruled out for an MI.  Now off dilt drip and
   on PO metoprolol TID.  On reduced amnio dose per EP recs.  Had TEE on
   [**3-11**] that showed no clot.  Patient converted to NSR post-TEE in the
   setting of
   hyperkalemia and has remained in NSR after electrolyte correction.
   Appreciate assistance from EP.
   - metoprolol held on evening of [**3-12**] and am [**3-13**] due to low blood
   pressures
   - notify EP when patient stable and leaving the unit to repeat
   assessment of his device (note they changed his baseline pacing rate to
   60 bpm on [**3-11**]).
   .
   # Abdominal pain: The patient did not have any abdominal pain on
   presentation.  He had mild discomfort on exam yesterday which appears
   to be worse today.  Abdominal ultrasound also noted sludge in the
   gallbladder, no other findings noted.  Pain could be secondary to a
   bilary process, bacteremia (?abdominal abscess), or some other process
   related to his colon cancer.
   - LFTs, amylase, lipase added on to am labs
   - consider non-contrast abdominal/pelvis CT scan
   .
   # Anemia: Chronically, likely iron deficiency from colon cancer.  Acute
   drop overnight likely secondary to orthopedic washout yesterday.
   Patient transfused with 1 unit on am of [**3-13**].  Will check pm hct.
   - Additional blood prn; pt. has one more unit in house.
   - continue iron replacement
   - obtain outpatient records.
   - Guaiac stools
   .
   # Colon Ca: No known mets but with extensive lymphadenopathy in chest
   on last CT scan.
   - obtain outpatient records.
   .
   # Pressure Ulcers:
   - local wound care, frequent turns
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: no h/o diabetes by chart.  HbA1c 6.7.  Will cover with
   humalog sliding scale q6h for now given steroids.
   .
   # Glaucoma: continue eye drops,
   - confirm pilocarpine dosing from outpatient setting.
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, NPO for now given potential for extubation
   today. ISS. initiate tube feeds as patient likely to be on vent for
   some time.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: D/c subcutaneous heparin for anemia (?blood loss) and
   start pneumoboots, PPI
   .
   # Access: A-line ([**2174-3-11**]), and R IJ central line ([**2174-3-11**])
   .

1. Respiratory Complications:
	* Pneumonia: The patient's sputum culture is growing GNRs, and they have a history of COPD, which increases the risk of pneumonia.
	* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is on mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of VAP.
	* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and they may require further respiratory support.
2. Cardiovascular Complications:
	* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which increases the risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
	* Myocardial infarction: The patient's cardiac enzymes are elevated, which may indicate myocardial damage.
	* Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and they may require further cardiac support.
3. Renal Complications:
	* Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and they have a history of pre-renal azotemia.
	* Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and they may require further renal support.
4. Infectious Complications:
	* Sepsis: The patient has bacteremia and septic arthritis, which increases the risk of sepsis.
	* Infections: The patient has multiple lines and tubes, which increases the risk of infections.
5. Metabolic Complications:
	* Hyperglycemia: The patient has a history of hyperglycemia, and their blood glucose levels are elevated.
	* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has an electrolyte imbalance, which may require further management.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, which increases the risk of further bleeding.
	* Abdominal pain: The patient has abdominal pain, which may be secondary to a bilary process, bacteremia, or another process related to their colon cancer.
7. Neurological Complications:
	* Seizures: The patient's electrolyte imbalance and cardiac arrhythmias may increase the risk of seizures.
	* Neurological compromise: The patient's neurological status is compromised, and they may require further neurological support.

Based on the patient's progress note, it is essential to closely monitor their vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage these potential complications.

   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  No clear evidence of pneumonia by CXR
   although possible posterobasilar infiltrate.  Urinary Legionella
   antigen negative.   Lactate mildly elevated on presentation, but lower
   after fluid resuscitation.  Some evidence for COPD exacerbation by
   history and in setting of steroid taper, but does not explain
   bacteremia and new A. Fib with RVR.  V/Q scan with low probability for
   PE.  [**Month (only) 11**] represent mild diastolic dysfunction [**2-7**] to a. fib with RVR
   causing pulmonary edema.  Lastly would consider aspiration.  Patient
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator with increased O2 requirements,
   which may be more difficult if ARF causes fluid retention.
   - Cont. to wean vent settings as tolerated to maximize extubation
   success
   - Cont nebulizers
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures from [**Location (un) 78**] growing MSSA.  Source
   unclear. ESR and CRP are markedly elevated and patient has septic
   joints as well.  Presentation not convincing for pneumonia, but cannot
   definitely rule out.  LAT CXR not of high enough quality to visualize
   retrocardiac opacity.  ID recommended CT torso, however, patient
   creatinine is acutely elevated and contrast at this time is likely to
   result in further kidney injury.  Sputum now growing GNRs. Mini BAL neg
   for polys or microorganisms.  If patient has increasing sputum or
   becomes febrile will consider adding gram negative coverage.  TEE on
   [**3-11**] was negative for vegetations on the valves and pacer lead, but
   given high grade bacteremia, a small vegetation may have been missed.
   - daily surveillance cultures
   - d6 nafcillin for MSSA bacteremia (Day 1 = [**2174-3-10**]), will likely need
   prolonged course
   .
   # ARF: Initially thought to be pre-renal as patient appeared
   underresuscitated on presentation and urine lytes consistent with
   pre-renal etiology.  Previous baseline 1.3-1.5 at [**Hospital1 1**] [**Location (un) 78**]. LOS
   I/Os documentation
 includes 4L patient received prior to arriving in
   the ICU.  Patient received multiple boluses of IVF overnight for low
   urine outputs with CVPs 10-11.  No evidence of UTI currently.  Renal
   ultrasound yesterday with right-sided hydronephrosis (of note patient
   has a mass lesion in left kidney previously documented at [**Hospital1 **] [**Location (un) 78**])
   but no evidence of abscess. Pt does have positive WBC on U/A [**2174-3-11**],
   but thought to be contaminant [**2-7**] Foley
urine eosinophils negative and
   repeat U/A negative for WBC and RBC
   - F/u Urology c/s for hydronephrosis
 will place nephrostomy drain if
   hydro worsens
   - Renal c/s
 no need for HD at this time, treat hyperphosphatemia with
   Renagel
   - renally dose meds (decreased nafcillin to 2 g Q6H for creatinine >
   4.0)
   - NS boluses and blood prn
   .
   # Septic arthritis / gout: Patient septic arthritis combined with gouty
   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - Slow taper of steroids started [**3-14**]
   - ortho following, JP drain to be pulled if output decreases
 F/u
   ortho recs
   .
   # Tachycardia: A. Fib with RVR
 appears to be a new diagnosis for this
   patient.  Likely not a candidate for coumadin given recent GI bleed and
   colon cancer.  Patient has ruled out for an MI.  Now off dilt drip and
   on PO metoprolol TID.  On reduced amnio dose per EP recs.  Had TEE on
   [**3-11**] that showed no clot.  Patient converted to NSR post-TEE in the
   setting of
   hyperkalemia and has remained in NSR after electrolyte correction.
   Appreciate assistance from EP.
   - now NSR
   - metoprolol being held for low SBP
   - notify EP when patient stable and leaving the unit to repeat
   assessment of his device (note they changed his baseline pacing rate to
   60 bpm on [**3-11**]).
   .
   # Abdominal pain: The patient did not have any abdominal pain on
   presentation.  He had mild discomfort on exam yesterday which appears
   to be worse today.  Abdominal ultrasound also noted sludge in the
   gallbladder, no other findings noted.  Pain could be secondary to a
   bilary process, bacteremia (?abdominal abscess), or some other process
   related to his colon cancer.
   - Trend LFTs
 elevated Tbili, other LFTs and lipase nl
   - consider non-contrast abdominal/pelvis CT scan
   .
   # Anemia: Chronically, likely iron deficiency from colon cancer.  Acute
   drop overnight likely secondary to orthopedic washout yesterday.
   Patient transfused with 1 unit on am of [**3-13**] and 2 U [**3-14**].
   - continue iron replacement
   - obtain outpatient records.
   - Guaiac stools
 neg x2
   .
   # Colon Ca: No known mets but with extensive lymphadenopathy in chest
   on last CT scan.
   - obtain outpatient records.
   .
   # Pressure Ulcers:
   - local wound care, frequent turns
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: no h/o diabetes by chart.  HbA1c 6.7.  Continue
   humalog sliding scale q6h for now given steroids.
   .
   # Glaucoma: continue eye drops
   - confirm pilocarpine dosing from outpatient setting.
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, ISS. initiate tube feeds as patient likely
   to be on vent for some time.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: HSC, pneumoboots, PPI
   .
   # Access: A-line ([**2174-3-11**]), and R IJ central line ([**2174-3-11**])
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient,  Wife
   .

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer, who presents with new onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and MSSA bacteremia, now with respiratory failure and acute kidney injury (ARF).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation with FiO2 40% and PEEP 5 cmH2O. The patient's oxygen saturation is 94%.
* Bacteremia: The patient has MSSA bacteremia, and the source is unclear. The patient's blood cultures are growing MSSA, and the patient has septic joints.
* Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's creatinine is elevated at 4.3 mg/dL, and the patient is receiving fluid resuscitation. The patient's urine output is low, and the patient is receiving diuretics.
* Septic arthritis/gout: The patient has septic arthritis combined with gouty arthritis in multiple joints. The patient's joints were tapped, and bacteria were found on gram stain.
* Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient has new onset atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is likely a new diagnosis. The patient is receiving metoprolol TID, and the patient's heart rate is 75 beats per minute.
* Abdominal pain: The patient has mild discomfort on exam, and the patient's abdominal ultrasound noted sludge in the gallbladder.
* Anemia: The patient is chronically anemic, likely due to iron deficiency from colon cancer. The patient's hemoglobin is 9.0 g/dL.
* Colon cancer: The patient has colon cancer with extensive lymphadenopathy in the chest on last CT scan.

The patient's medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further decline in oxygen saturation and increased risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia.
* Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia can lead to septic shock, organ dysfunction, and death.
* Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's ARF can worsen, leading to further decline in kidney function and increased risk of dialysis dependence.
* Septic arthritis/gout: The patient's septic arthritis/gout can lead to further joint damage, increased risk of sepsis, and prolonged hospital stay.
* Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR can lead to further cardiac complications, such as stroke, heart failure, and increased risk of death.
* Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain can worsen, leading to further decline in gastrointestinal function and increased risk of complications such as perforation or abscess.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen, leading to further decline in oxygen delivery to tissues and increased risk of complications such as heart failure and kidney injury.
* Colon cancer: The patient's colon cancer can progress, leading to further decline in quality of life and increased risk of death.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Weaning from mechanical ventilation
* Antibiotic therapy for MSSA bacteremia
* Fluid resuscitation for ARF
* Pain management for septic arthritis/gout
* Anti-coagulation therapy for atrial fibrillation with RVR
* Management of abdominal pain
* Iron replacement therapy for anemia
* Chemotherapy for colon cancer

The patient's ongoing medical issues include:

* Respiratory failure
* Bacteremia
* Acute kidney injury (ARF)
* Septic arthritis/gout
* Atrial fibrillation with RVR
* Abdominal pain
* Anemia
* Colon cancer

The patient's code status is full code, and the patient's disposition is ICU level of care.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with multiple comorbidities, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AFib), and chronic kidney disease (CKD). The patient has a history of septic arthritis, decubitus ulcer, and acute renal failure (ARF). The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation, and their condition is being managed with various medications, including fentanyl, morphine, and heparin.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2°C, heart rate of 75 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 100/34 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 94% on 40% FiO2. The patient's respiratory support is being provided through a ventilator, and their ABG values are within normal limits.

The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia, electrolyte imbalance, and mild kidney dysfunction. The patient's blood cultures are negative, and their BAL result is also negative.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) put them at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's history of septic arthritis and decubitus ulcer increases their risk for sepsis, particularly with the presence of a central line and the use of antibiotics.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's chronic kidney disease (CKD) and acute renal failure (ARF) put them at risk for AKI, which can further exacerbate their underlying kidney dysfunction.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance, particularly hypocalcemia, can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
5. Infection: The patient's central line and urinary catheter increase their risk for infection, particularly catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI).
6. Decubitus ulcer progression: The patient's decubitus ulcer is at risk for progression and potentially leading to further complications, such as sepsis and organ failure.
7. Pain management: The patient's chronic pain and acute pain require careful management to avoid complications, such as respiratory depression and medication overuse.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address their multiple comorbidities and potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities and complications. The patient's condition is complex, and multiple medical issues are present.

The patient's current medical issues include:

1. Hypocalcemia (low calcium levels)
2. Hypotension (low blood pressure)
3. Anemia
4. Hypothermia
5. Electrolyte and fluid disorder
6. Acute renal failure (ARF)
7. Septic arthritis (joint infection)
8. Decubitus ulcer (pressure sore)
9. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
10. Atrial fibrillation (AFib)
11. Pain control issues (acute and chronic pain)

The patient's laboratory results indicate:

1. Elevated white blood cell count (WBC)
2. Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
3. Elevated creatinine (Cr)
4. Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN)
5. Elevated potassium (K)
6. Elevated sodium (Na)
7. Elevated chloride (Cl)
8. Elevated bicarbonate (HCO3)
9. Elevated anion gap (AG)

The patient's physical examination reveals:

1. Intubation and sedation
2. Conjunctiva pale
3. Regular heart rate and rhythm
4. Normal S1 and S2 heart sounds
5. Coarse breath sounds
6. Soft, decreased bowel sounds
7. Tender abdomen
8. Bilateral knee and elbow swelling
9. Right wrist swelling

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Worsening of ARF
2. Development of septic shock
3. Increased risk of bleeding due to coagulopathy
4. Further compromise of respiratory function
5. Increased risk of infection due to prolonged ICU stay
6. Development of further organ dysfunction (e.g., liver, kidney, heart)
7. Increased risk of mortality due to the complexity of the patient's condition

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continued ICU care
2. Management of pain and sedation
3. Optimization of fluid and electrolyte balance
4. Management of ARF
5. Treatment of septic arthritis
6. Wound care for decubitus ulcer
7. Management of COPD
8. Cardioversion for AFib
9. Pain control measures

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities and complications. The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve outcomes.

   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  No clear evidence of pneumonia by CXR
   although possible posterobasilar infiltrate.  Urinary Legionella
   antigen negative.   Lactate mildly elevated on presentation, but lower
   after fluid resuscitation.  Some evidence for COPD exacerbation by
   history and in setting of steroid taper, but does not explain
   bacteremia and new A. Fib with RVR.  V/Q scan with low probability for
   PE.  [**Month (only) 11**] represent mild diastolic dysfunction [**2-7**] to a. fib with RVR
   causing pulmonary edema.  Lastly would consider aspiration.  Patient
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator with increased O2 requirements,
   which may be more difficult if ARF causes fluid retention. Had acute
   increase in O2 requirement on [**3-14**], likely multifactorial in nature
   (stacking pain meds, weaning vent settings, and worsening intravascular
   depletion).
   - Cont. to wean vent settings as tolerated to maximize extubation
   success, likely will not take place until renal failure / septic
   physiology improves
   - Continue to try PSV trials (20/5)
   - Coordinate the administration of pain meds to stagger over the course
   of the day
   - Cont nebulizers
   .
   # ARF: Initially thought to be pre-renal as patient appeared
   underresuscitated on presentation and urine lytes consistent with
   pre-renal etiology.  Previous baseline 1.3-1.5 at [**Hospital1 1**] [**Location (un) 78**]. LOS
   I/Os documentation
 includes 4L patient received prior to arriving in
   the ICU.  Patient received multiple boluses of IVF overnight for low
   urine outputs with CVPs 10-11.  No evidence of UTI currently.  Renal
   ultrasound yesterday with right-sided hydronephrosis (of note patient
   has a mass lesion in left kidney previously documented at [**Hospital1 **] [**Location (un) 78**])
   but no evidence of abscess. Pt had positive WBC on U/A [**2174-3-11**], but
   thought to be contaminant [**2-7**] Foley
urine eosinophils negative (argues
   against AIN) and repeat U/A negative for WBC and RBC. Low C3/C4 argues
   for immune complex damage - not specific, but argues for ATN in setting
   of recent prerenal ARF. Cr stable in 4+ range, which could represent a
   slowing of kidney damage.
   - Trend lytes
   - F/u Urology c/s for hydronephrosis
 will place nephrostomy drain if
   hydro worsens
   - Renal c/s
 no need for HD at this time, treat hyperphosphatemia with
   Renagel
 will add AlOH for increasing phos
   - Renally dose meds (decreased nafcillin to 2 g Q6H for creatinine >
   4.0)
   - NS boluses and blood prn, as UOP and CVP increase with fluid infusion
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures from [**Location (un) 78**] growing MSSA.  Source
   unclear. ESR and CRP are markedly elevated and patient has septic
   joints as well.  Presentation not convincing for pneumonia, but cannot
   definitely rule out.  LAT CXR not of high enough quality to visualize
   retrocardiac opacity.  ID recommended CT torso, however, patient

   [**3-11**] was negative for vegetations on the valves and pacer lead
 small

 so far are negative after the initial

   - d6 nafcillin for MSSA bacteremia (Day 1 = [**2174-3-10**]), will think about
   an endpoint to antibiotics as bld cx finalize
   .
   # Septic arthritis / gout: Patient septic arthritis combined with gouty
   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - Slow taper of steroids started [**3-14**]
   - F/u ortho recs
 pulled L knee JP drain this AM
   .
   # Tachycardia: A. Fib with RVR
 appears to be a new diagnosis for this
   patient.  Likely not a candidate for coumadin given recent GI bleed and
   colon cancer.  Patient has ruled out for an MI.  Now off dilt drip and
   on PO metoprolol TID.  On reduced amnio dose per EP recs.  Had TEE on
   [**3-11**] that showed no clot.  Patient converted to NSR post-TEE in the
   setting of
   hyperkalemia and has remained in NSR after electrolyte correction.
   Appreciate assistance from EP.
   - now NSR
   - metoprolol being held for low SBP
 will d/c for now, but continue
   amiodarone po as hemodynamics worsen with a-fib
   - notify EP when patient stable and leaving the unit to repeat
   assessment of his device (note they changed his baseline pacing rate to
   60 bpm on [**3-11**]).
   .

   - obtain outpatient records.

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and recently diagnosed colon cancer. He was admitted with acute respiratory failure, septic shock, and acute kidney injury. The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and is being treated with amiodarone and metoprolol.

The patient's respiratory status has been improving, with increased oxygen saturation and decreased respiratory rate. However, he continues to require high levels of oxygen supplementation and has had difficulty weaning from the ventilator.

The patient's kidney function has been declining, with a creatinine level of 4.3 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 119 mg/dL. He has been receiving fluid resuscitation and has had multiple boluses of IV fluids overnight. The patient's urine output has been low, and he has had a Foley catheter placed.

The patient has a diagnosis of septic arthritis and gouty arthritis, and has undergone orthopedic washout and joint aspiration. He has also had a bilateral pleural effusion drained.

The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with a potassium level of 4.2 mmol/L and a magnesium level of 2.4 mmol/L. He has been receiving IV fluids and electrolyte supplementation.

The patient's blood cultures have grown methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA), and he is being treated with nafcillin. He has also had a diagnosis of bacteremia, and is being treated with antibiotics.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he still requires high levels of oxygen supplementation and has had difficulty weaning from the ventilator. He may continue to experience respiratory failure if his underlying condition does not improve.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's kidney function has been declining, and he may continue to experience acute kidney injury if he does not receive adequate treatment.
3. Septic shock: The patient has a diagnosis of septic shock, and may continue to experience septic shock if his underlying condition does not improve.
4. Bacteremia: The patient has a diagnosis of bacteremia, and may continue to experience bacteremia if he does not receive adequate treatment.
5. Septic arthritis and gouty arthritis: The patient has a diagnosis of septic arthritis and gouty arthritis, and may continue to experience joint pain and swelling if his underlying condition does not improve.
6. Pressure ulcers: The patient is at risk for developing pressure ulcers due to his prolonged immobility and poor perfusion.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient has a diagnosis of hyperglycemia, and may continue to experience hyperglycemia if he does not receive adequate treatment.
8. Glaucoma: The patient has a diagnosis of glaucoma, and may continue to experience vision loss if his underlying condition does not improve.
9. Colon cancer: The patient has a diagnosis of colon cancer, and may continue to experience symptoms and complications related to his underlying condition.
10. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response: The patient has a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and may continue to experience arrhythmias and other cardiac complications if his underlying condition does not improve.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with A. Fib with RVR and bacteremia.
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures from [**Location (un) 78**] growing MSSA.  Source
   unclear. ESR and CRP are markedly elevated and patient has septic
   joints as well.  Presentation not convincing for pneumonia, but cannot
   definitely rule out.  LAT CXR not of high enough quality to visualize
   retrocardiac opacity.  ID recommended CT torso, however, patient
   creatinine is acutely elevated and contrast at this time is likely to
   result in further kidney injury.  Will defer bronchoscopy at present as
   patient has minimal secretions while intubated and no significant
   respiratory symptoms prior to intubation.  Sputum now growing GNRs.  If
   patient has increasing sputum or becomes febrile will consider adding
   gram negative coverage.  TEE on [**3-11**] was negative for vegetations on the
   valves and pacer lead, but given high grade bacteremia, a small
   vegetation may have been missed.
   - daily surveillance cultures
   - d4 nafcillin for MSSA bacteremia (Day 1 = [**2174-3-10**])
   - Will d/c daily EKGs to assess intervals
 not likely myositis
   - F/u mini-BAL results, per ID recs
   .
   # Septic arthritis / gout: Patient septic arthritis combined with gouty
   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - solumedrol 16 mg daily per rheum for gout; needs slow taper
   - ortho following, JP drain still in left knee
 F/u ortho recs
   .
   # Tachypnea/hypoxemia: Appears to be subacute exacerbation with decline
   over past 3-4 weeks.  No clear evidence of pneumonia by CXR although
   possible posterobasilar infiltrate.  Urinary Legionella antigen
   negative.   Lactate mildly elevated on presentation, but lower after
   fluid resuscitation.  Some evidence for COPD exacerbation by history
   and in setting of steroid taper, but does not explain bacteremia and
   new A. Fib with RVR.  V/Q scan with low probability for PE.  [**Month (only) 11**]
   represent mild diastolic dysfunction [**2-7**] to a. fib with RVR causing
   pulmonary edema.  Lastly would consider aspiration.  Patient electively
   intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Some difficulty
   weaning patient from vent early in the morning of [**3-13**].
   - Cont. to wean vent settings as tolerated
   - Antibiotics
   - nebulizers
   .
   # ARF: Likely predominantly pre-renal as patient appeared
   underresuscitated on presentation and urine lytes consistent with
   pre-renal etiology.  Previous baseline 1.3-1.5 at [**Hospital1 1**] [**Location (un) 78**]. LOS
   I/Os documentation
 includes 4L patient received prior to arriving in
   the ICU.  Patient received multiple boluses of IVF overnight for low
   urine outputs with CVPs 10-11.  No evidence of UTI currently.  Renal
   ultrasound yesterday with right-sided hydronephrosis (of note patient
   has a mass lesion in left kidney previously documented at [**Hospital1 **] [**Location (un) 78**])
   but no evidence of abscess. Pt does have positive WBC on U/A [**2174-3-11**],
   but thought to be contaminant [**2-7**] Foley
 add urine eosiniphils and
   repeat U/A
   - F/u Urology c/s (moderate right hydronephrosis)
   - Renal c/s in AM for worsening kidney failure.
   - renally dose meds (decrease nafcillin to 2 g Q6H if creatinine >
   4.0)
   - NS boluses and blood prn
   .
   # Tachycardia: A. Fib with RVR
 appears to be a new diagnosis for this
   patient.  Likely not a candidate for coumadin given recent GI bleed and
   colon cancer.  Patient has ruled out for an MI.  Now off dilt drip and
   on PO metoprolol TID.  On reduced amnio dose per EP recs.  Had TEE on
   [**3-11**] that showed no clot.  Patient converted to NSR post-TEE in the
   setting of
   hyperkalemia and has remained in NSR after electrolyte correction.
   Appreciate assistance from EP.
   - metoprolol held on evening of [**3-12**] and am [**3-13**] due to low blood
   pressures
   - notify EP when patient stable and leaving the unit to repeat
   assessment of his device (note they changed his baseline pacing rate to
   60 bpm on [**3-11**]).
   .
   # Abdominal pain: The patient did not have any abdominal pain on
   presentation.  He had mild discomfort on exam yesterday which appears
   to be worse today.  Abdominal ultrasound also noted sludge in the
   gallbladder, no other findings noted.  Pain could be secondary to a
   bilary process, bacteremia (?abdominal abscess), or some other process
   related to his colon cancer.
   - LFTs, amylase, lipase added on to am labs
   - consider non-contrast abdominal/pelvis CT scan
   .
   # Anemia: Chronically, likely iron deficiency from colon cancer.  Acute
   drop overnight likely secondary to orthopedic washout yesterday.
   Patient transfused with 1 unit on am of [**3-13**].  Will check pm hct.
   - Additional blood prn; pt. has one more unit in house.
   - continue iron replacement
   - obtain outpatient records.
   - Guaiac stools
   .
   # Colon Ca: No known mets but with extensive lymphadenopathy in chest
   on last CT scan.
   - obtain outpatient records.
   .
   # Pressure Ulcers:
   - local wound care, frequent turns
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: no h/o diabetes by chart.  HbA1c 6.7.  Will cover with
   humalog sliding scale q6h for now given steroids.
   .
   # Glaucoma: continue eye drops,
   - confirm pilocarpine dosing from outpatient setting.
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, NPO for now given potential for extubation
   today. ISS. initiate tube feeds as patient likely to be on vent for
   some time.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: D/c subcutaneous heparin for anemia (?blood loss) and
   start pneumoboots, PPI
   .
   # Access: A-line ([**2174-3-11**]), and R IJ central line ([**2174-3-11**])
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient,  Wife
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, chronic heart failure, and recently diagnosed colon cancer who presents with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and bacteremia. He has septic arthritis and gouty arthritis in multiple joints and was taken to the operating room for washout. He has acute kidney injury, likely pre-renal, and is being treated with antibiotics and fluid resuscitation. He has tachypnea and hypoxemia, which is likely due to a subacute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He has a high grade of bacteremia and is at risk for sepsis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a high grade of bacteremia and is at risk for sepsis. He is being treated with antibiotics and fluid resuscitation, but close monitoring is necessary to prevent sepsis.
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient has acute kidney injury, likely pre-renal, and is at risk for further kidney damage. He is being treated with antibiotics and fluid resuscitation, but close monitoring is necessary to prevent further kidney damage.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient has tachypnea and hypoxemia, which is likely due to a subacute exacerbation of COPD. He is at risk for respiratory failure and requires close monitoring and treatment.
4. Septic Shock: The patient has a high grade of bacteremia and is at risk for septic shock. He is being treated with antibiotics and fluid resuscitation, but close monitoring is necessary to prevent septic shock.
5. Pressure Ulcers: The patient has pressure ulcers and is at risk for further damage. He requires close monitoring and treatment to prevent further damage.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia and is at risk for further complications. He requires close monitoring and treatment to prevent further complications.
7. Glaucoma: The patient has glaucoma and is at risk for further complications. He requires close monitoring and treatment to prevent further complications.
8. Anemia: The patient has anemia and is at risk for further complications. He requires close monitoring and treatment to prevent further complications.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient requires close monitoring and treatment to prevent further complications. He requires antibiotics and fluid resuscitation to treat his bacteremia and acute kidney injury. He requires close monitoring of his respiratory status and treatment for his tachypnea and hypoxemia. He requires close monitoring of his blood glucose levels and treatment for his hyperglycemia. He requires close monitoring of his blood pressure and treatment for his hypertension. He requires close monitoring of his electrolyte levels and treatment for his electrolyte imbalances. He requires close monitoring of his wound care and treatment for his pressure ulcers.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  No clear evidence of pneumonia by CXR
   although possible posterobasilar infiltrate.  Urinary Legionella
   antigen negative.   Lactate mildly elevated on presentation, but lower
   after fluid resuscitation.  Some evidence for COPD exacerbation by
   history and in setting of steroid taper, but does not explain
   bacteremia and new A. Fib with RVR.  V/Q scan with low probability for
   PE.  [**Month (only) 11**] represent mild diastolic dysfunction [**2-7**] to a. fib with RVR
   causing pulmonary edema.  Lastly would consider aspiration.  Patient
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator with increased O2 requirements,
   which may be more difficult if ARF causes fluid retention.
   - Cont. to wean vent settings as tolerated to maximize extubation
   success
   - Cont nebulizers
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures from [**Location (un) 78**] growing MSSA.  Source
   unclear. ESR and CRP are markedly elevated and patient has septic
   joints as well.  Presentation not convincing for pneumonia, but cannot
   definitely rule out.  LAT CXR not of high enough quality to visualize
   retrocardiac opacity.  ID recommended CT torso, however, patient
   creatinine is acutely elevated and contrast at this time is likely to
   result in further kidney injury.  Sputum now growing GNRs. Mini BAL neg
   for polys or microorganisms.  If patient has increasing sputum or
   becomes febrile will consider adding gram negative coverage.  TEE on
   [**3-11**] was negative for vegetations on the valves and pacer lead, but
   given high grade bacteremia, a small vegetation may have been missed.
   - daily surveillance cultures
   - d6 nafcillin for MSSA bacteremia (Day 1 = [**2174-3-10**]), will likely need
   prolonged course
   .
   # ARF: Initially thought to be pre-renal as patient appeared
   underresuscitated on presentation and urine lytes consistent with
   pre-renal etiology.  Previous baseline 1.3-1.5 at [**Hospital1 1**] [**Location (un) 78**]. LOS
   I/Os documentation
 includes 4L patient received prior to arriving in
   the ICU.  Patient received multiple boluses of IVF overnight for low
   urine outputs with CVPs 10-11.  No evidence of UTI currently.  Renal
   ultrasound yesterday with right-sided hydronephrosis (of note patient
   has a mass lesion in left kidney previously documented at [**Hospital1 **] [**Location (un) 78**])
   but no evidence of abscess. Pt does have positive WBC on U/A [**2174-3-11**],
   but thought to be contaminant [**2-7**] Foley
urine eosinophils negative and
   repeat U/A negative for WBC and RBC
   - F/u Urology c/s for hydronephrosis
 will place nephrostomy drain if
   hydro worsens
   - Renal c/s
 no need for HD at this time, treat hyperphosphatemia
   - renally dose meds (decrease nafcillin to 2 g Q6H if creatinine >
   4.0)
   - NS boluses and blood prn
   .
   # Septic arthritis / gout: Patient septic arthritis combined with gouty
   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - Slow taper of steroids started [**3-14**]
   - ortho following, JP drain to be pulled if output decreases
 F/u
   ortho recs
   .
   .
   # Tachycardia: A. Fib with RVR
 appears to be a new diagnosis for this
   patient.  Likely not a candidate for coumadin given recent GI bleed and
   colon cancer.  Patient has ruled out for an MI.  Now off dilt drip and
   on PO metoprolol TID.  On reduced amnio dose per EP recs.  Had TEE on
   [**3-11**] that showed no clot.  Patient converted to NSR post-TEE in the
   setting of
   hyperkalemia and has remained in NSR after electrolyte correction.
   Appreciate assistance from EP.
   - metoprolol held on evening of [**3-12**] and am [**3-13**] due to low blood
   pressures
   - notify EP when patient stable and leaving the unit to repeat
   assessment of his device (note they changed his baseline pacing rate to
   60 bpm on [**3-11**]).
   .
   # Abdominal pain: The patient did not have any abdominal pain on
   presentation.  He had mild discomfort on exam yesterday which appears
   to be worse today.  Abdominal ultrasound also noted sludge in the
   gallbladder, no other findings noted.  Pain could be secondary to a
   bilary process, bacteremia (?abdominal abscess), or some other process
   related to his colon cancer.
   - LFTs, amylase, lipase added on to am labs
   - consider non-contrast abdominal/pelvis CT scan
   .
   # Anemia: Chronically, likely iron deficiency from colon cancer.  Acute
   drop overnight likely secondary to orthopedic washout yesterday.
   Patient transfused with 1 unit on am of [**3-13**].  Will check pm hct.
   - Additional blood prn; pt. has one more unit in house.
   - continue iron replacement
   - obtain outpatient records.
   - Guaiac stools
   .
   # Colon Ca: No known mets but with extensive lymphadenopathy in chest
   on last CT scan.
   - obtain outpatient records.
   .
   # Pressure Ulcers:
   - local wound care, frequent turns
   .
   # Hyperglycemia: no h/o diabetes by chart.  HbA1c 6.7.  Will cover with
   humalog sliding scale q6h for now given steroids.
   .
   # Glaucoma: continue eye drops,
   - confirm pilocarpine dosing from outpatient setting.
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, NPO for now given potential for extubation
   today. ISS. initiate tube feeds as patient likely to be on vent for
   some time.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: D/c subcutaneous heparin for anemia (?blood loss) and
   start pneumoboots, PPI
   .
   # Access: A-line ([**2174-3-11**]), and R IJ central line ([**2174-3-11**])
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient,  Wife
   .
   # Disposition: Requires ICU level of care.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen due to the presence of A. Fib with RVR, which may lead to increased oxygen requirements and difficulty weaning from the ventilator.
2. Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia is likely to persist or worsen due to the presence of MSSA in the blood cultures, which may lead to septic shock and multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's AKI is likely to worsen due to the presence of pre-renal azotemia, which may lead to further kidney damage and the need for renal replacement therapy.
4. Septic Arthritis/Gout: The patient's septic arthritis/gout may worsen due to the presence of bacteria in the joints, which may lead to further joint damage and the need for prolonged antibiotic therapy.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is likely to worsen due to the presence of steroids and the need for insulin therapy, which may lead to further complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis.
6. Pressure Ulcers: The patient's pressure ulcers are likely to worsen due to the presence of immobility and the need for further wound care, which may lead to further complications such as infection and sepsis.
7. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding is likely to worsen due to the presence of colon cancer and the need for further endoscopic procedures, which may lead to further bleeding and the need for transfusions.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to worsen due to the presence of chronic blood loss and the need for further transfusions, which may lead to further complications such as sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.

In summary, the patient is at risk for several potential medical complications, including respiratory failure, bacteremia, AKI, septic arthritis/gout, hyperglycemia, pressure ulcers, gastrointestinal bleeding, and anemia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of invasive rectosigmoid adenocarcinoma. He has undergone various medical and surgical interventions, including a renal scan, which showed no uptake bilaterally due to poor renal perfusion. The patient has a history of anemia, with a current hemoglobin level of 23 g/dL.

The patient's current medical condition is complex, with multiple comorbidities. He has a urinary tract infection (UTI) with GNRs, which has been treated with ciprofloxacin, cefepime, and flagyl. He also has a central line infection, which has been treated with cefepime and ciprofloxacin.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 81 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 127/44 mmHg. He is receiving respiratory support with a ventilator and oxygen therapy.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine (4.3 mg/dL) and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) (23 mg/dL), indicating renal impairment. His liver function tests (LFTs) are slightly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 41 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 64 IU/L.

The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypokalemia (potassium level of 3.8 mEq/L), hypocalcemia (calcium level of 6.6 mg/dL), and hypomagnesemia (magnesium level of 2.4 mg/dL). His blood glucose level is slightly elevated at 119 mg/dL.

The patient's medical plan includes ongoing treatment for his UTI and central line infection, as well as management of his renal impairment and electrolyte imbalances. He is also scheduled to undergo a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan and a positron emission tomography (PET) scan to assess the extent of his cancer.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level is elevated, indicating possible AKI. This can lead to fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and the need for dialysis.
2. Septic shock: The patient's UTI and central line infection can lead to septic shock, which can result in organ failure and death.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he requires ongoing respiratory support. Pneumonia or other respiratory complications can lead to respiratory failure and death.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypokalemia and hypocalcemia, can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
5. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's cancer and underlying medical conditions can increase the risk of hemorrhagic complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or hematuria.
6. Infection-related complications: The patient's central line infection can lead to bacteremia or sepsis, which can result in organ failure and death.
7. Renal failure: The patient's renal impairment can progress to renal failure, which can require dialysis and impact the patient's quality of life.

In summary, the patient's condition is complex and requires ongoing monitoring and management of his multiple comorbidities. Potential medical complications can arise from his condition, and close monitoring and prompt intervention are necessary to prevent these complications and improve the patient's outcome.

   INTERPRETATION: Flow and dynamic images were obtained after intravenous

   FINDINGS: The gallbladder is moderately distended, measuring up to 6 cm

   The wall is not thickened. A 13-mm shadowing stone is present with a
   small
   amount of sludge. A tiny amount of pericholecystic fluid is present,
   but
   is non=specific, particularly in the presence of a small amount of
   ascites
   also found elsewhere about the liver. There is no intra- or extra-
   hepatic
   biliary ductal dilatation. The flow in the main portal vein is

   significantly changed, but with no specific features for cholecystitis.
   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  No clear evidence of pneumonia by CXR
   although possible posterobasilar infiltrate.  Urinary Legionella
   antigen negative.   Lactate mildly elevated on presentation, but lower
   after fluid resuscitation.  Some evidence for COPD exacerbation by
   history and in setting of steroid taper, but does not explain
   bacteremia and new A. Fib with RVR.  V/Q scan with low probability for
   PE.  [**Month (only) 11**] represent mild diastolic dysfunction [**2-7**] to a. fib with RVR
   causing pulmonary edema.  Lastly would consider aspiration.  Patient
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator with increased O2 requirements,
   which may be more difficult if ARF causes fluid retention. Had acute
   increase in O2 requirement on [**3-14**], likely multifactorial in nature
   (stacking pain meds, weaning vent settings, and worsening intravascular
   depletion).
   - Cont. to wean vent settings as tolerated to maximize extubation
   success, likely will not take place until renal failure / septic
   physiology improves
   - Continue to try PSV trials (20/5)
   - Coordinate the administration of pain meds to stagger over the course
   of the day

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications are potential concerns:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient's oxygen requirements are increasing, and weaning from the ventilator is difficult.
2. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and the urine output is decreased. The patient has been treated with diuretics and IV fluids, but the kidney function is not improving.
3. Bacteremia: The patient has a positive blood culture for MSSA, and the source of the infection is unclear. The patient is receiving antibiotic treatment, but the infection is not responding.
4. Sepsis: The patient has septic arthritis and gouty arthritis, which may be contributing to the bacteremia and respiratory failure.
5. Tachycardia: The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which may be contributing to the increased heart rate and blood pressure.
6. Abdominal pain: The patient has mild abdominal discomfort, which may be related to a bilary process, bacteremia, or another process related to the colon cancer.
7. Anemia: The patient has a chronic anemia, which may be related to iron deficiency and anemia of chronic disease from the colon cancer. The acute drop in hemoglobin overnight may be secondary to the orthopedic washout.
8. Pressure ulcers: The patient has a pressure ulcer, which requires local wound care and frequent turns.
9. Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, which may be related to the steroids and the lack of insulin therapy.
10. Glaucoma: The patient has glaucoma, which requires eye drops and may require further treatment.

The patient's medical history is significant for colon cancer, chronic kidney disease, and atrial fibrillation. The patient is currently receiving treatment for bacteremia, sepsis, and respiratory failure. The patient's condition is unstable, and further evaluation and treatment are necessary to address the underlying medical complications.

   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  No clear evidence of pneumonia by CXR
   although possible posterobasilar infiltrate.  Urinary Legionella
   antigen negative.   Lactate mildly elevated on presentation, but lower
   after fluid resuscitation.  Some evidence for COPD exacerbation by
   history and in setting of steroid taper, but does not explain
   bacteremia and new A. Fib with RVR.  V/Q scan with low probability for
   PE.  [**Month (only) 11**] represent mild diastolic dysfunction [**2-7**] to a. fib with RVR
   causing pulmonary edema.  Lastly would consider aspiration.  Patient
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator with increased O2 requirements,
   which may be more difficult if ARF causes fluid retention. Had acute
   increase in O2 requirement on [**3-14**], likely multifactorial in nature
   (stacking pain meds, weaning vent settings, and worsening intravascular
   depletion).
   - Cont. to wean vent settings as tolerated to maximize extubation
   success, likely will not take place until renal failure / septic
   physiology improves
   - Continue to try PSV trials (20/5)
   - Coordinate the administration of pain meds to stagger over the course
   of the day
   - Cont nebulizers
   .
   # ARF: Initially thought to be pre-renal as patient appeared
   underresuscitated on presentation and urine lytes consistent with
   pre-renal etiology.  Previous baseline 1.3-1.5 at [**Hospital1 1**] [**Location (un) 78**]. LOS
   I/Os documentation
 includes 4L patient received prior to arriving in
   the ICU.  Patient received multiple boluses of IVF overnight for low
   urine outputs with CVPs 10-11.  No evidence of UTI currently.  Renal
   ultrasound yesterday with right-sided hydronephrosis (of note patient
   has a mass lesion in left kidney previously documented at [**Hospital1 **] [**Location (un) 78**])
   but no evidence of abscess. Pt had positive WBC on U/A [**2174-3-11**], but
   thought to be contaminant [**2-7**] Foley
urine eosinophils negative (argues
   against AIN) and repeat U/A negative for WBC and RBC. Low C3/C4 argues
   for immune complex damage - not specific, but argues for ATN in setting
   of recent prerenal ARF. Cr stable in 4+ range, which could represent a
   slowing of kidney damage.
   - Trend lytes
   - F/u Urology c/s for hydronephrosis
 will place nephrostomy drain if
   hydro worsens
   - Renal c/s
 no need for HD at this time, treat hyperphosphatemia with
   Renagel
 will add AlOH for increasing phos
   - Renally dose meds (decreased nafcillin to 2 g Q6H for creatinine >
   4.0)
   - NS boluses and blood prn, as UOP and CVP increase with fluid infusion
   .
   # Fever/bacteremia:  Blood cultures from [**Location (un) 78**] growing MSSA.  Source
   unclear. ESR and CRP are markedly elevated and patient has septic
   joints as well.  Presentation not convincing for pneumonia, but cannot
   definitely rule out.  LAT CXR not of high enough quality to visualize
   retrocardiac opacity.  ID recommended CT torso, however, patient
   creatinine is acutely elevated and contrast at this time is likely to
   result in further kidney injury.  Sputum now growing GNRs. Mini BAL neg
   for polys or microorganisms.  If patient has increasing sputum or
   becomes febrile will consider adding gram negative coverage.  TEE on
   [**3-11**] was negative for vegetations on the valves and pacer lead
 small
   vegetation cannot be ruled out.
   - daily surveillance cultures
 so far are negative after the initial
   positive bld cx
   - d6 nafcillin for MSSA bacteremia (Day 1 = [**2174-3-10**]), will think about
   an endpoint to antibiotics as bld cx finalize
   .
   # Septic arthritis / gout: Patient septic arthritis combined with gouty
   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - Slow taper of steroids started [**3-14**]
   - F/u ortho recs
 pulled L knee JP drain this AM
   .
   # Tachycardia: A. Fib with RVR
 appears to be a new diagnosis for this
   patient.  Likely not a candidate for coumadin given recent GI bleed and
   colon cancer.  Patient has ruled out for an MI.  Now off dilt drip and
   on PO metoprolol TID.  On reduced amnio dose per EP recs.  Had TEE on
   [**3-11**] that showed no clot.  Patient converted to NSR post-TEE in the
   setting of
   hyperkalemia and has remained in NSR after electrolyte correction.
   Appreciate assistance from EP.
   - now NSR
   - metoprolol being held for low SBP
 will d/c for now, but continue
   amiodarone po as hemodynamics worsen with a-fib
   - notify EP when patient stable and leaving the unit to repeat
   assessment of his device (note they changed his baseline pacing rate to
   60 bpm on [**3-11**]).
   .
   # Abdominal pain: The patient did not have any abdominal pain on
   presentation.  He had mild discomfort on exam yesterday which appears
   to be worse today.  Abdominal ultrasound also noted sludge in the
   gallbladder, no other findings noted.  Pain could be secondary to a
   bilary process, bacteremia (?abdominal abscess), or some other process
   related to his colon cancer.
   - Trend LFTs
 elevated Tbili, other LFTs and lipase nl

   .

   orthopedic washout yesterday.  Patient transfused with 1 unit on am of
   [**3-13**] and 2 U [**3-14**]. Haptoglobin not decreased and LDH not largely
   elevated, so hemolysis less likely
   - continue iron replacement

 neg x2

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer, who presents with new onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (A. Fib with RVR), respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury (ARF). The patient has a positive blood culture for MSSA and is being treated with antibiotics. He also has septic arthritis and gouty arthritis in multiple joints, and has undergone orthopedic washout and joint aspirations.

The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of factors, including COPD exacerbation, pneumonia, and aspiration. The patient's ARF is likely pre-renal in nature, but the possibility of ATN or post-renal ARF cannot be ruled out. The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is receiving dialysis.

The patient's bacteremia is likely due to MSSA, and he is being treated with antibiotics. The patient's septic arthritis and gouty arthritis are being treated with antibiotics and joint aspirations.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure may be complicated by pneumonia, which could lead to further respiratory deterioration.
2. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and septic arthritis may lead to sepsis, which could result in multi-organ dysfunction.
3. ARF: The patient's ARF may worsen, leading to further kidney damage and potentially requiring hemodialysis.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen, leading to further cardiac complications.
5. Septic shock: The patient's septic arthritis and bacteremia may lead to septic shock, which could result in further organ dysfunction.
6. Pressure ulcers: The patient's prolonged bedrest and immobility may lead to pressure ulcers.
7. Infection: The patient's respiratory and urinary tract infections may lead to further complications, such as sepsis or organ failure.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of GI bleed and colon cancer may lead to further gastrointestinal bleeding.
9. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen, leading to further complications such as ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome.
10. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance may worsen, leading to further complications such as cardiac arrhythmias or muscle weakness.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for MSSA bacteremia and septic arthritis.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubation if necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's kidney function closely and consider dialysis if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and consider cardioversion if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely and correct any imbalances.
6. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels closely and adjust insulin therapy as necessary.
7. Consider stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Consider pressure ulcer prevention measures to prevent skin breakdown.
9. Consider infection control measures to prevent further infections.
10. Consider further evaluation of the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding and colon cancer.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old male with a complex medical history, including CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer. He is currently admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, ARF, and bacteremia.

The patient's respiratory failure is characterized by subacute exacerbation with a decline over the past 3-4 weeks. The CXR shows a possible posterobasilar infiltrate, but no clear evidence of pneumonia. The patient has been electively intubated to perform multiple procedures.

The patient's ARF is initially thought to be pre-renal, but the renal ultrasound yesterday showed right-sided hydronephrosis, and the patient's creatinine has been stable in the 4+ range. The patient has been receiving multiple boluses of IVF overnight for low urine outputs, and the CVPs have been 10-11.

The patient has a history of bacteremia, and his blood cultures from [**Location (un) 78**] grew MSSA. The source of the bacteremia is unclear, and the patient has septic joints as well. The patient's sputum is now growing GNRs, and a mini BAL was negative for polys or microorganisms.

The patient has a history of tachycardia, which is now attributed to A. Fib with RVR. The patient has been off dilt drip and on PO metoprolol TID, and he has been converted to NSR post-TEE.

The patient's abdominal pain is likely secondary to a bilary process, bacteremia, or some other process related to his colon cancer. The patient's anemia is likely secondary to chronic disease from colon cancer, and the acute drop overnight is likely secondary to orthopedic washout.

The patient has a history of colon cancer, and his CT scan showed extensive lymphadenopathy in the chest. The patient's pressure ulcers require local wound care and frequent turns.

The patient's hyperglycemia is managed with a humalog sliding scale q6h, and his glaucoma is managed with eye drops.

The patient requires ICU-level care, and his disposition will be discussed with his family regarding the escalation of care in regards to worsening renal failure and prolonged intubation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Prolonged intubation and weaning from the ventilator
2. Worsening of ARF and potential need for hemodialysis
3. Development of septic shock and multi-organ failure
4. Increased risk of pressure ulcers and skin breakdown
5. Development of hyperglycemia and glucose toxicity
6. Increased risk of infection and bacteremia
7. Development of gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation
8. Worsening of colon cancer and potential need for further surgical intervention
9. Development of cardiac arrhythmias and potential need for cardioversion
10. Increased risk of mortality and morbidity due to the patient's complex medical history and ongoing medical complications.

   bacteremia and new A. Fib with RVR.  V/Q scan with low probability for
   PE.  [**Month (only) 11**] represent mild diastolic dysfunction [**2-7**] to a. fib with RVR
   causing pulmonary edema.  Lastly would consider aspiration.  Patient

   which may be more difficult if ARF causes fluid retention. Had acute
   increase in O2 requirement on [**3-14**], likely multifactorial in nature
   (stacking pain meds, weaning vent settings, and worsening intravascular
   depletion).

   success, likely will not take place until renal failure / septic

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer, who presents with new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia. He is also experiencing respiratory failure and acute kidney injury (AKI). The patient has undergone multiple procedures, including elective intubation, and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's medical history is significant for CAD, CHF, and colon cancer, and he has recently undergone a colonoscopy and has a mass lesion in his left kidney. He has also had a recent GI bleed and has been taking steroids.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation due to worsening respiratory failure.
* AKI: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and he is experiencing oliguria.
* Bacteremia: The patient has MSSA bacteremia, which is being treated with nafcillin.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient has newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is being treated with amiodarone.
* Septic arthritis: The patient has septic arthritis in multiple joints, which is being treated with antibiotics and joint aspiration.
* Gout: The patient has gouty arthritis, which is being treated with colchicine.
* Abdominal pain: The patient is experiencing abdominal pain, which is being evaluated with imaging studies.

Potential medical complications:

* Worsening respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to underlying lung disease, pneumonia, or other respiratory complications.
* AKI: The patient's AKI may worsen due to underlying kidney disease, sepsis, or other factors.
* Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia may lead to septic shock, multi-organ failure, or other complications.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen due to underlying heart disease, electrolyte imbalances, or other factors.
* Septic arthritis: The patient's septic arthritis may lead to joint destruction, septic shock, or other complications.
* Gout: The patient's gout may lead to joint destruction, septic shock, or other complications.
* Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain may worsen due to underlying gastrointestinal disease, perforation, or other complications.

Assessment and plan:

* The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management.
* The patient's respiratory failure and AKI require aggressive treatment, including mechanical ventilation and renal replacement therapy.
* The patient's bacteremia requires antibiotic therapy, and the source of the infection should be investigated.
* The patient's atrial fibrillation requires anticoagulation therapy, and the patient should be monitored for bleeding complications.
* The patient's septic arthritis and gout require antibiotic therapy and joint aspiration.
* The patient's abdominal pain requires further evaluation with imaging studies and potential surgical intervention.
* The patient's nutritional status should be monitored and optimized, and the patient should be considered for enteral nutrition if possible.
* The patient's glycemic control should be monitored and optimized, and the patient should be considered for insulin therapy if necessary.
* The patient's electrolyte imbalances should be monitored and optimized, and the patient should be considered for electrolyte replacement therapy if necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer, who presented with new onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and MSSA bacteremia, and is currently experiencing respiratory failure and acute renal failure (ARF). He has been intubated for multiple procedures and is having difficulty weaning off the ventilator due to fluid retention and baseline COPD. The patient has also developed septic arthritis and gouty arthritis in multiple joints, and has a mass lesion on the left previously seen on CT scan.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine level is still in the 4+ range, and his urine output is not increasing despite fluid resuscitation. This may indicate a worsening of ARF, which could lead to further electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, with a requirement for high levels of ventilatory support. This may lead to further complications such as pneumonia, atelectasis, or respiratory failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a history of MSSA bacteremia and septic arthritis, and may be at risk for further septic complications.
4. Gouty Arthritis: The patient's gouty arthritis may worsen with further inflammation and joint damage, leading to chronic pain and disability.
5. Pressure Ulcers: The patient's prolonged bedrest and immobility may lead to pressure ulcers, which could become infected and complicate his recovery.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels are not well-controlled, and he may be at risk for further hyperglycemic complications such as ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic coma.
7. Electrolyte Imbalances: The patient's electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypokalemia, may worsen with further fluid resuscitation and may lead to cardiac arrhythmias or muscle weakness.
8. Infection: The patient's septic arthritis and bacteremia may lead to further infections, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, or skin infections.
9. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's history of colon cancer and recent gastrointestinal bleeding may lead to further bleeding complications.
10. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's history of CAD and CHF may lead to further cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction, heart failure, or arrhythmias.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust fluid resuscitation and medication dosing accordingly.
2. Continue to provide respiratory support and monitor the patient's respiratory status closely.
3. Continue to treat the patient's septic arthritis and gouty arthritis with antibiotics and anti-inflammatory medications.
4. Monitor the patient's pressure ulcers and take measures to prevent further skin breakdown.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust insulin dosing accordingly.
6. Monitor the patient's electrolyte imbalances and adjust medication dosing accordingly.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's infection risk and take measures to prevent further infections.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding risk and take measures to prevent further bleeding complications.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular risk and take measures to prevent further cardiovascular complications.

   This is a 78 y/o M h/o CAD, CHF, and recently diagnosed colon cancer
   who presents with new onset A. Fib with RVR and MSSA bacteremia, now
   with respiratory failure and ARF.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Presented with subacute exacerbation with
   decline over past 3-4 weeks.  Has COPD at baseline. Patient was
   electively intubated on [**3-11**] to perform multiple procedures.  Difficulty
   weaning patient from the ventilator initially due to fluid retention
   and baseline COPD. [**Month (only) 11**] be extubatable today as pt doing well on minimal

 worth, [**Date range (1) 4714**]), to

   .

d yesterday

recommends checking CT abd without contrast for

d (see above)
   - Renally dose meds
   .

   arthritis in multiple joints.  Orthopedics took patient to the OR for
   washout on [**3-12**] and all joints tapped have bacteria on gram stain.
   Assistance and recs from ortho and rheum are much appreciated.
   - colchicine off given elevated creatinine
   - Slow taper of steroids started [**3-14**]
   - F/u ortho recs
 ask if further procedures are planned in near future
   .

 appears to be a new
   diagnosis for this patient.  Likely not a candidate for coumadin given
   recent GI bleed and colon cancer.  Patient has ruled out for an MI. Had
   TEE on [**3-11**] that showed no clot.  Patient converted to NSR post-TEE in
   the setting of hyperkalemia and has remained in NSR after electrolyte
   correction.  Appreciate assistance from EP.
   - now NSR
   - metoprolol being held for low SBP
 will continue amiodarone po
   - notify EP when patient stable and leaving the unit to repeat
   assessment of his device (note they changed his baseline pacing rate to
   60 bpm on [**3-11**]).
   .
   # Abdominal pain: The patient did not have any abdominal pain on
   presentation.  He had mild discomfort on exam yesterday which appears
   to be worse today.  Abdominal ultrasound also noted sludge in the
   gallbladder, no other findings noted.  Pain could be secondary to a
   bilary process, bacteremia (?abdominal abscess), or some other process
   related to his colon cancer.
   - Trend LFTs
 elevated Tbili, other LFTs and lipase nl
   - RUQ U/S showing cholelithiasis, no cholecystitis. Had CT abd

   .

   - confirm pilocarpine dosing from outpatient setting.
   .
